data.sampled:
You can do this with strftime method :
Python :
from datetime import datetime
date = datetime.strptime('2020-09-10', '%Y-%m-%d')
sentence = date.strftime("%A, %B %d, %Y.")
print(sentence)

JavaScript :
new Date('2020-09-10').toLocaleString('default', { weekday: 'long', year: 'numeric', month: 'long', day: 'numeric' })

data.sampled:
I hope you are talking about 21th century dates, otherwise I have no idea how April 19th 1945 can be converted to a sentence, since the concept of a "month" was not defined before the current era, as explained [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Month#Pre-Nomenclature).

Assuming you meant "19th April 1945", I was raised to write sentences in British English and I was also taught that "4th of July" is the correct way to write "4th July", so here goes:

"Monday, the nineteenth of April, in the year of our Lord, one thousand nine hundred and forty-five."
